GitHub open in new window

  • Install the Snyk CLI

    • Install the Snyk CLI with npm or Yarn
    • Install with standalone executables
    • Install with Homebrew (macOS, Linux)
    • Install with Scoop (Windows)
    • Snyk CLI in a Docker image
    • Install as a part of a Snyk integration

# Install the Snyk CLI

You can install the Snyk CLI using the methods explained on this page.

After you install the Snyk CLI, you must authenticate. You can then can get started testing and fixing your vulnerabilities, beginning with testing your installation.

# Install the Snyk CLI with npm or Yarn

Before installing the Snyk CLI using npm, be sure you have installed the prerequisites:

  • Install the latest version of npm in your local environment, using Node version 12 or later. See What version of Node is required for Snyk?open in new window for the steps to update Node.
  • To run Snyk on Alpine Linux, first install libstdc++. See How can I use CLI on an Alpine operating system?open in new window for more information.

Then follow these steps to install with npm or Yarn:

Snyk CLI is available as an npm packageopen in new window. If you have Node.js installed locally, you can install the npm package by running npm install snyk -g.

If you are using Yarn, install by running yarn global add snyk.

# Install with standalone executables

Use GitHub Releasesopen in new window to download a standalone executable (macOS, Linux, Windows) of Snyk CLI for your platform.

Snyk also provides these standalone executables on the Snyk Content Delivery Network (CDN). See https://static.snyk.io/cli/latest/release.jsonopen in new window for the download links. Examples for a specific version or platform follow:

  • https://static.snyk.io/cli/v1.666.0/release.jsonopen in new window
  • https://static.snyk.io/cli/latest/snyk-macosopen in new window

For example, to download and run the latest Snyk CLI on macOS, you could run:

curl https://static.snyk.io/cli/latest/snyk-macos -o snyk
chmod +x ./snyk
mv ./snyk /usr/local/bin/
1
2
3

You can also use these direct links to download the executables:

  • macOS: https://static.snyk.io/cli/latest/snyk-macosopen in new window
  • Windows: https://static.snyk.io/cli/latest/snyk-win.exeopen in new window
  • Linux: https://static.snyk.io/cli/latest/snyk-linuxopen in new window
  • Linux/arm64: https://static.snyk.io/cli/latest/snyk-linux-arm64open in new window
  • Alpine: https://static.snyk.io/cli/latest/snyk-alpineopen in new window

{% hint style="warning" %} Note: The drawback of this method is that you must keep the Snyk CLI up to date manually. {% endhint %}

# Install with Homebrew (macOS, Linux)

Install Snyk CLI from Snyk tapopen in new window with Homebrewopen in new window by running:

brew tap snyk/tap
brew install snyk
1
2

# Install with Scoop (Windows)

Install Snyk CLI from the Snyk bucketopen in new window with Scoopopen in new window on Windows:

scoop bucket add snyk https://github.com/snyk/scoop-snyk
scoop install snyk
1
2

# Snyk CLI in a Docker image

Snyk CLI can also be run from a Docker image. Snyk offers multiple Docker images under snyk/snyk-cliopen in new window and snyk/snykopen in new window (see snyk/snyk-images on GitHubopen in new window for more details).

These images wrap the Snyk CLI and depending on the Tag come with relevant tooling for different projects, for example, for scanning a Gradle project with snyk/snyk-cli:

docker run -it
    -e "SNYK_TOKEN=<TOKEN>"
    -v "<PROJECT_DIRECTORY>:/project"
    -v "/home/user/.gradle:/home/node/.gradle"
  snyk/snyk-cli:gradle-5.4 test --org=my-org-name
1
2
3
4
5

# Install as a part of a Snyk integration

Snyk also offers many integrations into developer tooling. These integrations install and manage the Snyk CLI for you. Integrations include the following:

  • Snyk Jenkins pluginopen in new window
  • CircleCI Orbopen in new window
  • Azure Pipelines Taskopen in new window
  • GitHub Actionsopen in new window
  • IntelliJ IDE Pluginopen in new window
  • VS Code Extensionopen in new window
  • Eclipse IDE Extensionopen in new window
  • Maven pluginopen in new window

See the integrations docs for more details.
